H+

Human+AI Education

Empowering Educators in the AI Era

This content was generated by AI and reviewed by Avi Salmon for reliability.

The Teacher in the AI Era

A Discussion Document

Should lecturers and teachers themselves possess the required competencies, or should their primary expertise lie in the ability to cultivate these competencies in their students?

As artificial intelligence changes how we learn, teach, and work, a real question opens up about what we expect from educators. This document does not try to settle that question. It lays out the competencies at stake, the tensions involved, and the arguments on each side, as a basis for an informed discussion.

The Five Competencies

These are the competencies identified as critical in an AI-rich world. The first four were selected through a roundtable consensus process. The fifth, ethical judgment, was added because AI raises questions of integrity, fairness, and responsibility that cut across all the others.

1
Critical Thinking
Asking good questions, evaluating information sources, detecting errors and bias, distinguishing confidence from accuracy, and verifying claims rather than accepting them at face value.
2
Self-Directed Learning
Metacognition, self-regulation, adaptability, and the willingness to update one's practices and beliefs when the landscape shifts.
3
Teamwork and Interpersonal Communication
Working effectively with others: co-constructing knowledge, negotiating perspectives, communicating across differences, and navigating group dynamics in environments where AI changes what each person contributes.
4
Solving Complex Problems
Breaking down multifaceted, poorly defined problems. Integrating knowledge across domains, weighing trade-offs, and designing solutions under real-world constraints, including knowing when and how to use AI as part of the process.
5
Ethical Judgment and Responsible Use
Navigating questions of integrity, intellectual ownership, fairness, transparency, and accountability when working with powerful tools.

A guiding principle runs through all five: keeping the human above the machine. Across each competency, the goal is to maintain human judgment, creativity, and moral responsibility as the final authority over any tool or system.

Questions for Discussion

The central question leads to a set of more specific tensions. For each one, two directions of argument are presented.

1. What counts as "sufficient" mastery?

If teachers need to possess these competencies, how much is enough? And who gets to define that threshold?

Direction A

A minimal, practical level of personal experience is enough. Teachers do not need to be experts. They need just enough lived practice to speak from experience rather than theory. Setting the bar too high risks creating unrealistic standards that discourage educators rather than help them.

Direction B

"Minimum" is dangerously vague. Without clear and substantive benchmarks, "sufficient" becomes whatever is convenient. If students face real complexity, their teachers need more than surface familiarity. Superficial mastery leads to superficial modeling.

2. Can pedagogical expertise substitute for personal practice?

Can a teacher who deeply understands a competency but has not practiced it still cultivate it effectively in students?

Direction A

Great teachers are primarily designers of learning experiences. A skilled pedagogue can structure activities, scaffold inquiry, and guide student growth without being a practitioner of every skill they teach. Teaching is its own expertise.

Direction B

Complex cognitive skills like critical thinking, ethical judgment, and self-directed learning are learned primarily through modeling. Students learn by watching the teacher think, not just by following instructions. Without personal practice, the teacher delivers rules instead of demonstrations. Students can tell the difference.

3. Do all five competencies require the same depth of teacher experience?

Or are some competencies more dependent on lived practice than others?

Direction A

Some competencies are more procedural and can be taught effectively through well-designed activities. For example, verification strategies for critical thinking, or structured frameworks for solving complex problems. Not every competency demands deep personal experience.

Direction B

The competencies that matter most (ethical judgment, self-directed learning, critical thinking under pressure) are inherently experiential. They involve navigating uncertainty, ambiguity, and discomfort. These cannot be reduced to procedures. They require a teacher who has genuinely grappled with them.

4. How should limited professional development time be allocated?

Training time and resources are limited. Should they go toward building teachers' own competencies, or toward their ability to teach them?

Direction A

Professional development should focus on pedagogical strategies: how to design activities, assess student growth, and facilitate discussion around these competencies. Teaching skills are transferable. Personal mastery of every competency is not realistic at scale.

Direction B

Investing in teachers' personal competency development is not a luxury. It is a prerequisite. Professional development that skips personal practice produces teachers who can explain competencies but cannot demonstrate them. The investment in possession is what makes cultivation possible.

5. What is the role of teacher vulnerability and "not-knowing"?

Should teachers model uncertainty and learning in real time, or do students need confident authority?

Direction A

Students need stability and confidence. A teacher who frequently exposes uncertainty risks undermining their authority and creating anxiety. Especially in younger age groups, learners need a secure knowledge figure, not a fellow traveler.

Direction B

In a world where confident-sounding answers are instantly available from AI, the most valuable thing a teacher can model is honest uncertainty. Saying "I don't know, let's find out together" teaches students that not-knowing is the starting point of inquiry, not a failure.

6. How would we assess whether a teacher has "enough" competency?

If possession matters, what does evaluation look like for something this personal and contextual?

Direction A

Competency can be assessed through structured rubrics, portfolio evidence, peer observation, and reflective practice documentation. Assessment does not require perfection. It requires showing that the teacher has engaged meaningfully with each competency area.

Direction B

These competencies are deeply contextual and relational. Trying to assess them through checklists or rubrics risks reducing them to performative compliance. The best indicator is not a score but whether a teacher's students actually develop these competencies. That is hard to measure and slow to appear.

7. Does the answer change across contexts?

Is the possess-vs-cultivate balance different for primary school versus university, STEM versus humanities, or across cultures and resource levels?

Direction A

Context matters enormously. Young children need teachers who model social-emotional competencies above all. University lecturers face students who already use AI independently. Resource-poor environments must prioritize differently than well-funded systems. One answer cannot fit all.

Direction B

The core principle holds across contexts: you cannot cultivate what you have not practiced. The specific depth and emphasis may vary, but the fundamental relationship between teacher possession and student development is universal. Adjusting for context is reasonable; abandoning the principle is not.

This document is a starting point for discussion, not a position paper. The questions above draw on research in cognitive apprenticeship, epistemic authority, moral development, transfer theory, and emerging studies on AI and education. The goal is to support an informed conversation about what we expect from teachers in a rapidly changing world.

References & Resources

The following sources inform the discussion above. Each entry links to the original publication or a stable archive.

Foundational Research

  • Cognitive Apprenticeship (Collins, Brown & Holum, 1991) – American Educator – Learning through expert modeling; making thinking processes visible
  • Self-Efficacy (Bandura, 1997) – Cambridge University Press – How belief in one’s capabilities shapes performance and agency
  • Transfer of Learning (Perkins & Salomon, 1992) – Harvard / Web Archive – How knowledge and skills transfer across contexts and domains
  • Moral Development in the Professions (Rest & Narvaez, 1994) – Psychology Press – Framework for understanding moral reasoning and ethical judgment
  • Moral Character Development (Lapsley & Woodbury, 2016) – Wiley – Social-cognitive approaches to character and moral education
  • Teacher Clarity, Immediacy & Credibility (Zheng, 2021) – Frontiers in Psychology – How teacher communication behaviors affect student learning outcomes

AI & Education Research

  • Generative AI and Critical Thinking (Microsoft Research, 2025) – Microsoft Research – Evidence that AI use may reduce critical thinking effort
  • AI in Teacher Education (Jose et al., 2025) – European Journal of Teacher Education – Preparing teachers for AI-era challenges in education
  • ChatGPT Meta-Analysis (Wang & Fan, 2025) – Nature Humanities & Social Sciences – ChatGPT boosts performance when scaffolded; risks shallow learning otherwise
  • GenAI & Critical Thinking in Higher Education (Nasr et al., 2025) – Education Sciences (MDPI) – Passive AI use hinders critical thinking; guided use enhances it
  • Critical Thinking Instruction (Abrami et al., 2015) – Educational Research Review – Meta-analysis on effective strategies for teaching critical thinking
  • Inoculation-Based Approach to AI Misinformation (Zarzosa et al., 2025) – Journal of the Learning Sciences – Building student resilience against AI-generated misinformation

Frameworks & Standards

  • UNESCO AI Competency Framework for Teachers (2024) – UNESCO – 15 competencies across 5 dimensions for teaching with and about AI
  • UNESCO AI Competency Frameworks Overview – UNESCO – Overview of frameworks for both students and teachers
  • OECD AI Literacy Framework – OECD Education Today – Framework for youth AI literacy and responsible use
  • What Should Teachers Teach in an AI Future? – OECD Publishing – Rethinking curriculum and pedagogy for powerful AI
  • Teachers’ Professional Learning for the AI Era – OECD Education 2040 (PDF) – Skills and knowledge teachers need for AI integration
  • ISTE Standards for Educators – ISTE – Technology competency standards for teachers
  • ISTE Standards for Students – ISTE – Technology and digital citizenship standards for learners

Real-World Case Studies & Reporting

  • AI’s Future for Students Is in Our Hands (Brookings, 2026) – Brookings Institution – AI risks outweigh benefits for students without structured guidance
  • Ohio State Requires AI Fluency for All Students (Fortune, 2025) – Fortune – University mandates AI literacy as a graduation requirement
  • AI Trust Gap: Students vs. Teachers (Fast Company, 2024) – Fast Company – Survey reveals divergent trust in AI between students and educators
  • 86% of Students Already Use AI (Campus Technology, 2024) – Campus Technology – Student AI adoption outpaces institutional guidance
  • Rising AI Use in Schools Brings Big Downsides (EdWeek, 2025) – Education Week – Challenges from widespread AI use in K-12 education
